Everything.First paragraph: The Obama administration on Tuesday outlined an ambitious plan for slashing U.S. greenhouse-gas pollution over the next decade, calling for accelerating the shift from fossil fuels to clean energy to stave off the worst effects of climate change.
Everything.Caption: Silhouetted against the sky at dusk, emissions spew from the smokestacks at Westar Energy’s Jeffrey Energy Center coal-fired power plant near St. Mary’s, Kan. (Charlie Riedel/AP)
Everything.Title: Obama administration, citing climate risks, plans steep cuts in greenhouse-gas pollution

First paragraph.text: Iraqi soldiers and Shiite militia took back the center of the Iraqi city of Tikrit on Tuesday from Islamic State militants. It figures to be a major victory against the Islamists, although there are indications that fighting may continue.

Everything.Caption: Iraqi security forces and Shiite paramilitary fighters hold an Islamic State flag, which they pulled down in Tikrit on Tuesday. Iraqi troops aided by Shi’ite paramilitaries and Sunni tribal fighters have reached the center of Tikrit after securing the Sunni city’s southern and western sections from the militants, Prime Minister Haidar al-Abadi said. (Alaa al-Marjani/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Photos: The battle in Tikrit as the Islamic State loses control

Everything.Caption: Trevor Noah in 2009. (Bongiwe Mchunu/The Star via Associated Press)
Everything.Title: How Trevor Noah can save his tenure at ‘The Daily Show’ before it starts

Everything.Caption: Members of a Turkish police special forces unit prepare to enter the Justice Palace in Istanbul on March 31. (Osman Orsal/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Turkish prosecutor dies after being held hostage in a courthouse, reports say

First paragraph.text: Organizers of a mainline Protestant church gathering say they will not move their 2017 convention from Indianapolis due to a hotly contested new Religious Freedom Restoration Act as initially planned.

Everything.Caption: Sharon Watkins is general minister and president of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). Photo used with permission, http://disciples.org
Everything.Title: Disciples of Christ will hold its convention in Indianapolis despite religious freedom law

Everything.First paragraph: This post has been updated.
Everything.Caption: Musician Joni Mitchell performs at the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz International Trumpet Competition and Herbie Hancock Tribute in Hollywood October 28, 2007. (Max Morse/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Singer-songwriter Joni Mitchell hospitalized after being found unconscious

First paragraph.text: Before toy stores were stocked with pet plants, virtual pets and pillow pets, an advertising copywriter called Gary Ross Dahl was dreaming up the Pet Rock, a 1970s novelty toy craze since called a “ridiculously successful marketing scheme.”

Everything.Caption: Gary Ross Dahl, the creator of the popular 1970s fad the Pet Rock, has died at age 78 in Oregon. Dahl’s wife, Marguerite Dahl, confirmed that her husband of 40 years died March 23 of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. (Marguerite Dahl via AP)
Everything.Title: Pet Rock inventor Gary Dahl dies at 78. He put a rock in a box and sold millions.

Everything.First paragraph: This post has been updated.
Everything.Caption: Hundreds of students gathered at Duke Wednesday after a noose was found on campus. (Photo obtained by the Post.)
Everything.Title: Noose is found hanging from tree on Duke’s campus

Everything.First paragraph: In 1979, a balding man with a touch of gray at the temples and glasses like windshields was holding forth on his favorite subject: H2O. Pat Brown, former governor of California — and father of current California governor Jerry Brown (D) — was asking: What’s the value of water?
Everything.Caption: Former California governor Edmund G. “Pat” Brown and his wife, Bernice, after their son, Gov. Edmund G. “Jerry” Brown Jr., was inaugurated to his second term in Sacramento in 1979. (Walter Zaboski/AP)
Everything.Title: Jerry Brown battles Calif. water crisis created by his father, Gov. Pat Brown

Everything.First paragraph: Back when Sen. Bob Menendez was just a chubby Cuban American kid in a tenement apartment in Union City, New Jersey, his mother instilled in him one, all-important lesson: “failure is not an option.” With that mantra in mind, Menendez embarked on a remarkable rise from poverty to power that culminated in the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Capitol Hill.
Everything.Caption: The Park Hyatt Paris Vendôme (Courtesy of Hyatt Hotels)
Everything.Title: Sen. Bob Menendez: Humble beginnings to a 5-star, $1,000 per night Paris hotel suite

Everything.First paragraph: Hillary Clinton is still leading all comers in early polls of the 2016 presidential race. But these days, that has much more to do with the Republicans' weaknesses than with her strengths.
Everything.Caption: Hillary Clinton listens before delivering remarks at an event in New York on Nov. 21, 2014. (AP Photo/Bebeto Matthews, File)
Everything.Title: Hillary Clinton’s favorable rating drops below 50 percent. And yet she still leads big.

Everything.First paragraph: CHICAGO -- Mayor Rahm Emanuel went to the polls Thursday morning to cast his ballot during early voting in his runoff election.
Everything.Caption: Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel casts his ballot early in the mayoral runoff election on Thursday in Chicago. (By Sean Sullivan/The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: Rahm Emanuel votes, jokes media is his ‘family’
10 quotations from the late Rev. Robert H. Schuller that could inspire anyone

Everything.First paragraph: A student has admitted hanging a noose from a tree on campus, Duke University officials said Thursday afternoon.
Everything.Caption: This photo provided by Henry Washington shows a rope noose hung from a tree Wednesday, April 1, 2015, in Durham, N.C. Duke University officials are trying to determine who hung the noose, what the president of the elite Southern school described as a vicious symbol in a region where lynchings were once used to terrorize black residents. (AP Photo/Henry Washington)
Everything.Title: Duke student admitted hanging noose from tree on campus, school officials say

Everything.First paragraph: Anthony Ray Hinton was one of Alabama’s longest-serving death row inmates, having spent more than half his life incarcerated. Now, after three decades of insisting that he was innocent in the 1985 murders of two men, the 58-year-old Hinton is finally a free man.
Everything.Caption: Anthony Ray Hinton wipes tears following his release. (Bob Farley/EPA)
Everything.Title: Alabama inmate free after three decades on death row. How the case against him unraveled.

First paragraph.text: For a very brief time on Saturday, the moon will turn an orangey-red, depending on conditions, during an Easter weekend lunar eclipse. Although the east coast of the United States will be shut out of this particular “blood moon” in the sky, it’s just the third of four such eclipses spanning a period of a couple years — an event known as a tetrad.

Everything.Caption: The moon glows a red hue during a total lunar eclipse Tuesday, April 15, 2014, as seen from the Milwaukee area. That eclipse was the first of four total lunar eclipses to take place between 2014 to 2015. (AP Photo/Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel, Mike De Sisti)
Everything.Title: Everything you need to know about the ‘blood moon’ apocalypse debate

Everything.First paragraph: The Final Four is usually a time to celebrate the best teams in college basketball, not extend the debate over the amateur game’s best player. That has changed some this year with NBA executives and scouts in agreement that either Duke freshman center Jahlil Okafor or Kentucky freshman big man Karl-Anthony Towns will be the No. 1 pick come June.
Everything.Caption: The general consensus is Duke’s Jahlil Okafor, above, or Kentucky’s Karl-Anthony Towns will go No. 1 in the NBA draft. (Grant Halverson/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Final Four provides chance to debate NBA’s No. 1 pick

First paragraph.text: The water situation in California is getting downright scary. Last week, the Department of Water Resources found “no snow whatsoever” in its Sierra Nevada snowpack survey and Gov. Jerry Brown declared mandatory reductions in water usage in the state. In particular, the more than 400 agencies supplying water to urban areas will have to cut total usage by 25 percent below 2013 levels.

Everything.Caption: A sprinkler waters a lawn at San Francisco’s Golden Gate Park on Wednesday. As California enters its fourth year of severe drought and the state’s snowpack is at record lows, Gov. Jerry Brown has ordered a statewide 25 percent mandatory water usage reduction for residents, businesses and farms. (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: How to get Californians to use less water — without forcing them to

Everything.First paragraph: This guy.
Everything.Caption: Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images
Everything.Title: Why is the White House Easter Bunny always so creepy?

Everything.First paragraph: President Obama and the first family worshiped  Easter Sunday  at the 212-year-old Alfred Street Baptist Church in Alexandria, where the minister mixed bible verse with social justice.
Everything.Caption: President Obama, accompanied by the Easter Bunny, at Easter Egg Roll festivities at the White House in 2012. (J. Scott Applewhite/AP)
Everything.Title: Obama family visits historic African American church in Northern Virginia

First paragraph.text: Presented at a meeting nine years ago in Bethesda, the paper “After the Crisis Initiative: Healing from Trauma after Disasters” offered solid advice for mental-health practitioners who wish to avoid re-traumatizing victims. The language was academic, but the message was simple: Believe.

Everything.Caption: The Columbia Graduate School of Journalism has released a report explaining why Rolling Stone got a story about an alleged rape at the University of Virginia’s Phi Kappa Psi house, above, so wrong. (Ateve Helber/AP)
Everything.Title: Why Rolling Stone went easy on ‘our rape victim’

Everything.Caption: Students pass by the Phi Kappa Psi house at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville in January. (Steve Helber/Associated Press)
Everything.Title: After Rolling Stone’s retraction, remembering what reporters owe rape victims

Everything.First paragraph: When an Arab coalition led by Saudi Arabia began dropping bombs on Yemen last month, one of its first targets was Sanaa International Airport. The airfield in Yemen’s capital is used by both commercial and military aircraft, and was a strategic target after Shiite rebels forced the country’s president to flee Yemen.
Everything.Caption: Satellite imagery of Sanaa International Airport taken March 22. (Image by DigitalGlobe)
Everything.Title: New satellite images of Yemen — before and after airstrikes

Everything.First paragraph: Gertrude Weaver, who became the world’s oldest person last week, died Monday morning in Arkansas after suffering complications from pneumonia.
Everything.Caption: Gertrude Weaver poses at Silver Oaks Health and Rehabilitation Center in Camden, Ark., in July, the day before her 116th birthday. (Danny Johnston/AP)
Everything.Title: Gertrude Weaver dies just five days after becoming the world’s oldest person

Everything.First paragraph: It’s a story heartwarming enough to bring a tear to the most jaded sportswriter’s eye: In ninth grade, childhood friends make a pact to conquer the NCAA. And, a few years later, they do — overcoming personal tragedy, the cutthroat machinations of college sports, and the sheer unlikelihood that what some kid says when he is in high school means something along the way.
Everything.Caption: Jahlil Okafor, No. 15, and Tyus Jones, No. 5, of the Duke University Blue Devils celebrate after defeating the Wisconsin Badgers during the NCAA Men’s Final Four national championship in Indianapolis. Duke defeated Wisconsin 68-63. (Streeter Lecka/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: How Duke’s Tyus Jones and Jahlil Okafor conquered the NCAA: Friendship

Everything.First paragraph: PRINCESS ANNE, Md. — He was still trying to keep the lights on when his children all died in their beds.
Everything.Caption: Makayla Collins Jackson, 6 and sister Adriahna Collins Jackson, 8, lay flowers on the doorstep of the Todd family after Rodney Todd and his seven children were found dead in their home. (Linda Davidson/The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: Carbon monoxide blamed after father and his 7 children die in their sleep

First paragraph.text: President Obama launched an initiative Tuesday aimed at highlighting the connections between climate change and public health, bringing both medical and data experts to the White House this week.

Everything.Caption: Steam rises from the coal-fired Jim Bridger Power Plant outside Point of Rocks, Wyo. (Jim Urquhart/Reuters)
Everything.Title: The White House wants to explore how climate change makes you sick

Everything.First paragraph: When the college basketball world checked into Indianapolis late last week, the expectation was that history would be made in Lucas Oil Dome on Monday night. It was — but not the way everyone thought.
Everything.Caption: Coach Mike Krzyzewski and his Duke players Jahlil Okafor, Tyus Jones, Amile Jefferson, Grayson Allen, Marshall Plumlee, Quinn Cook and Justise Winslow watch a highlight video after defeating Wisconsin to win the national championship. (Andy Lyons/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Mike Krzyzewski’s fifth title at Duke might be his most surprising

Everything.First paragraph: Often, neighbors spotted 88-year-old Rosalia Juskin and her 100-year-old husband, Michael, walking around together outside in their Elmwood Park, N.J., neighborhood. Other times, he walked alone — surprisingly active for his 100 years — and she tended to the garden she loved.
Everything.Caption: Authorities at the Elmwood Park, N.J., home where the bodies of an elderly couple were found on Monday. (Tariq Zehawi/Northjersey.com via AP)
Everything.Title: 100-year-old killed his sleeping wife with an ax in a gruesome murder-suicide

Everything.First paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — It began in November 2013 with the coordinated co-announcement by highly touted recruits Tyus Jones and Jahlil Okafor that they were headed to Durham, and continued a few days later when — after keeping his friends in the dark for a few days — Justise Winslow announced that he, too, would be a Blue Devil.
Everything.Caption: Justise Winslow is headed to the NBA while Grayson Allen will be a key cog for Duke next year. (Andy Lyons/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: After leading Duke to title, these fabulous freshmen will leave holes for next year

Everything.First paragraph: If you thought all the whistles were going in favor of Duke this NCAA tournament, you were right.
Everything.Caption: Duke’s Grayson Allen battles for a loose ball against Wisconsin’s Traevon Jackson Monday night. (David J. Phillip/Associated Press)
Everything.Title: Duke really did get all the foul calls in the 2015 NCAA tournament

Everything.First paragraph: Is there anyone out there? The answer is almost certainly yes, a top NASA scientist said this week.
Everything.Caption: (Illustration courtesy of NASA)
Everything.Title: Why NASA’s top scientist is sure that we’ll find signs of alien life in the next decade

Everything.First paragraph: Most members of Congress will tell you that they’re a champion of small business. However, most can’t truly empathize, because they haven’t actually run a small business. Even fewer have started one from scratch.
Everything.Caption: Sen. Rand Paul announced on April 7 that he is running for the GOP nomination. (AFP PHOTO / MICHAEL B. THOMAS).
Everything.Title: What a Rand Paul White House could mean for businesses

Everything.First paragraph: The Obama administration late Wednesday called for a ban on so-called “conversion” therapies that promise to cure gay and transgender people.
Everything.Caption: Protestors march to the Justice department after a rally in response to the suicide of transgender Ohio teenager Leelah Alcorn, on January, 10, 2015 in Washington, DC. (Bill O’Leary/The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: White House condemns therapy to ‘cure’ gay youth

Everything.First paragraph: Bob Schieffer, longtime CBS newsman and anchor of “Face the Nation,” announced Wednesday that he will retire come summer, concluding a long career covering politics. Over his 50 years in the field, Schieffer has become a beloved figure in journalism, admired not only for his on-air skills but also for his courtesy and humility in a business rife with vanity.
Everything.Caption: Panelist P.J. O’Rourke, left, looks on as Bob Schieffer acknowledges audience applause after announcing his retirement from CBS News at the close of the Schieffer Symposium on the News at TCU in Fort Worth, Texas, Wednesday, April 8, 2015. (AP Photo/The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, Ron T. Ennis)
Everything.Title: Veteran broadcaster Bob Schieffer announces retirement after more than 50 years in the business

Everything.First paragraph: Sabra Dipping Co., which makes the top-selling brand of hummus in the United States, has voluntarily pulled 30,000 cases of hummus — about 360,000 containers nationwide — from stores after s sample tested positive for the potentially deadly bacterium Listeria monocytogenes.
Everything.Caption: Sabra, the top-selling hummus brand in the United States, has recalled 30,000 cases of hummus after a sample tested positive for Listeria. (istockphoto)
Everything.Title: Sabra pulls 30,000 cases of hummus off store shelves because of Listeria fears

Everything.First paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The vast majority of Cubans welcome warmer relations with the United States, holding high expectations that closer ties pledged by the two countries will shake up the island’s troubled economy, according to a new survey of Cuban citizens. But they are doubtful that the diplomatic detente will bring political reforms to their communist country.
Everything.Caption: A mural in the city of Santiago de Cuba reads “Long Live the Revolution.” (Sarah L. Voisin/The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: Poll shows vast majority of Cubans welcome closer ties with U.S.

Everything.First paragraph: Hearing horrible news about a child is hard enough for any parent. But seeing it may be worse. Thanks to the video showing a white police officer shooting and killing an unarmed black man over the weekend, two mothers in South Carolina were exposed to images of events in their sons’ lives that both desperately wish had never happened.
Everything.Caption: Judy Scott, mother of Walter Scott, who was shot in the back and killed by North Charleston, S.C., Police Officer Michael Slager, pauses while speaking to a few reporters at her home on April 8 in Charleston, S.C. (Ricky Carioti/The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: South Carolina killing of Walter Scott leaves two mothers grieving and praying

First paragraph.text: At least 12 people were pulled from the wreckage of a restaurant that was destroyed when a tornado ripped through northern Illinois on Thursday, according to reports.

Everything.Caption: (Courtesy of Jon Seidel/Chicago Sun-Times)
Everything.Title: This Illinois restaurant was destroyed by a tornado. Everybody inside survived.

Everything.First paragraph: What would have happened if the man with the cellphone had taken a different path to work?
Everything.Caption: The area where Walter Scott was shot last weekend. (Alex Holt/For The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: S.C. investigators say they thought fatal police shooting was suspicious before video emerged

First paragraph.text: An editorial in today’s New York Times originally said:

Everything.Caption: Convention attendees look at weapons on display at the 2015 NRA Annual Convention in Nashville, Tennessee on April 10, 2015. The annual NRA meeting and exhibit, expected to draw over 70,000 people, runs till April 12. AFP PHOTO / KAREN BLEIERKAREN BLEIER/AFP/Getty Images
Everything.Title: From “the ultimate in hypocrisy” to “this may run counter to the N.R.A.’s ideas”

Everything.First paragraph: This post has been updated.
Everything.Caption: Shelly Sterling, estranged wife of former Los Angeles Clippers basketball team owner Donald Sterling, leaves for the lunch break during her lawsuit against V. Stiviano in Los Angeles Superior Court on March 25. (Nick Ut/AP)
Everything.Title: Donald Sterling’s estranged wife wins back millions he lavished on V. Stiviano

Everything.First paragraph: “Stand off! Stand off! The gun is loaded,” comes the disembodied voice on the dispatch radio.
Everything.Caption: The suspect, Mario Valencia, walks with a loaded gun moments before a patrol car strikes him from behind. (Marana Police Department via Reuters)
Everything.Title: Dashcam video shows Arizona cop running over armed suspect with patrol car

Everything.First paragraph: When disgruntled Florida mailman Doug Hughes landed his ultralight gyrocopter on the West Lawn of the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday, he was hoping to stir a debate about campaign finance reform. And maybe he did.
Everything.Caption: In March, Doug Hughes flies his gyrocopter near the Wauchula Municipal Airport in Wauchula, Fla. Police didn’t immediately identify the man who steered his one-person helicopter onto the West Lawn of the U.S. Capitol, but Hughes, a Florida postal carrier, took responsibility for the stunt on a Web site. (James Borchuck/Tampa Bay Times via AP)
Everything.Title: Flying mailman becomes most audacious gyrocopter pilot since James Bond

Everything.First paragraph: The already massive Indian Ocean search zone for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 will double if wreckage of the missing aircraft isn’t located, government officials said.
Everything.Caption: A crew member looks out an observation window aboard a Royal New Zealand Air Force P3 Orion maritime search aircraft as it flies over the southern Indian Ocean, looking for MH370 debris, in 2014. (Richard Polden/Reuters file)
Everything.Title: MH370 search area will be doubled if Malaysia Airlines plane isn’t found

Everything.First paragraph: Former Rhode Island governor Lincoln Chafee launched another series of hits on Hillary Clinton’s foreign policy credentials Thursday, accusing her of repeated diplomatic clumsiness, and again highlighting her 2002 vote to authorize the use of military force in Iraq.
Everything.Caption: Former Rhode Island governor Lincoln Chafee last week launched an exploratory committee, potentially setting up a Democratic challenge to former secretary of state Hillary Clinton. (AP Photo/Steven Senne)
Everything.Title: Lincoln Chafee accuses Hillary Clinton of diplomatic clumsiness, says ‘America loves an underdog’

Everything.First paragraph: The number of middle and high school students using electronic cigarettes tripled between 2013 and 2014, according to government figures released Thursday, a startling increase that public health officials fear could reverse decades of efforts combating the scourge of smoking.
Everything.Caption: (Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: High school, middle school kids now use more e-cigs than tobacco: CDC

Everything.First paragraph: Five family members were found dead inside a Phoenix home Thursday evening after an apparent dispute over the family business burst into gunfire. The discovery brought to a close an hours-long standoff that had a residential street swarming with SWAT team officers and police.
Everything.Caption: Members of the Phoenix Police Department stand in front of a home where authorities say five people were killed after a shooting Thursday in Phoenix. (Ross D. Franklin/AP)
Everything.Title: Five dead in family dispute after hours-long standoff at Phoenix home

Everything.First paragraph: After four long days living like America’s poor, Gwyneth Paltrow broke her much-mocked attempt at shopping on a food stamp budget in search of some chicken and black licorice.
Everything.Caption: Gwyneth Paltrow arrives at the Oscars on Feb. 22 at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles. (Jordan Strauss/Invision via AP)
Everything.Title: A hungry Gwyneth Paltrow fails the food-stamp challenge four days in

Everything.Caption: Britt McHenry (ESPN)
Everything.Title: Britt McHenry’s ‘Mean Girls’ routine evokes little sympathy

Everything.First paragraph: Today in BEE NEWS (that’s a thing, right? Let’s just pretend it’s a thing): A truck loaded with millions and millions of honeybees overturned on a highway in Washington state, releasing just so many bees Friday morning.
Everything.Caption: Beekeepers hard at work at the scene. (Ian Terry/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Truck carrying millions of bees tips over on highway

First paragraph.text: Cardinal Francis George, who died Friday, leaves an indelible mark on Catholicism in the United States as an immensely influential religious leader. George, the previous archbishop of Chicago and a former president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, died at 78 after a protracted battle with cancer.

Everything.Caption: Cardinal Francis George of Chicago died after a long battle with cancer on April 17 at his residence in Chicago. (Scott Olson/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: 5 points you need to know about the death of Cardinal George

Everything.First paragraph: Saturday morning, President Obama gave a speech on climate change — to preview a bigger speech on climate change.
Everything.Caption: A bird flies over the sensitive ecological landscape of the Everglades National Park, home to many endangered and rare plants on March 16, 2015 in Miami, Florida. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Obama will visit the Florida Everglades on Earth Day — to talk about climate change

Everything.First paragraph: Islamic State militants in Libya shot and beheaded two groups of Ethiopian Christians, a video purportedly from the extremists showed Sunday, according to the Associated Press.
Everything.Caption: This image made from a video released by Islamic State militants on Sunday shows a group of captured Ethiopian Christians taken to a beach before they were killed by Islamic State militants, in Libya. (Militant video via AP)
Everything.Title: Purported ISIS video shows militants killing groups of Ethiopian Christians

Everything.First paragraph: Islamic State militants in Libya shot and beheaded two groups of Ethiopian Christians, a video purportedly from the extremists showed Sunday, according to the Associated Press.
Everything.Caption: This image made from a video released by Islamic State militants on Sunday shows a group of captured Ethiopian Christians taken to a beach before they were killed by Islamic State militants, in Libya. (Militant video via AP)
Everything.Title: Purported ISIS video shows militants killing groups of Ethiopian Christians

Everything.First paragraph: This post has been updated.
Everything.Caption: The White House early Monday morning. (The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: Another White House fence-jumper arrested

Everything.First paragraph: This past Lord’s Day, Tim Tebow had a message for the world. He cribbed it from a well-known letter from the Apostle Paul to his friends in Christ.
Everything.Caption: Left: Tim Tebow in 2014. (Brynn Anderson/AP). Right: Michael Vick in 2014. (Jemal Countess/Getty Images for Saks Fifth Avenue)
Everything.Title: Tim Tebow, welcome to Philadelphia, the city of second chances

Everything.First paragraph: Tulsa County Sheriff Stanley Glanz said Monday that two officers present when a reserve deputy shot and killed a man have been reassigned after receiving threats.
Everything.Caption: A protest outside the Tulsa County sheriff’s office last week. (James Gibbard/Tulsa World via AP)
Everything.Title: Tulsa sheriff says deputies seen in shooting video were reassigned after receiving threats

First paragraph.text: Reports of the worst ever migrant sea disaster on the Mediterranean — where as many as 850 migrants are thought to have drowned this weekend — had European officials scrambling to address the crisis at what is being called the world’s “deadliest border crossing.”

Everything.Caption: Local residents and rescue workers help a migrant woman after a boat carrying migrants sank off the island of Rhodes in southeastern Greece on April 20. (AFP/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: The real reason for the Mediterranean migrant crisis

First paragraph.text: An Iowa farm must destroy up to 5.3 million hens after the deadly bird flu virus was found among its flock, the U.S. Department of Agriculture announced Monday.

Everything.Caption: A flock of turkeys at a Minnesota poultry farm. Nearly 8 million chickens and turkeys have been infected in an outbreak of bird flu in the Midwest, including 5.3 million hens at an Iowa farm. (Bethany Hahn/AP)
Everything.Title: Millions of hens to be euthanized at Iowa farm with bird flu

First paragraph.text: The jury that convicted Dzhokhar Tsarnaev for the Boston Marathon bombing gathered Tuesday to begin figuring out how he should be punished. Will Tsarnaev be sentenced to die by lethal injection? Or will he be sentenced to life in prison without parole?

Everything.Caption: Martin Richard’s family, from left: Denise, his mother; Henry, his brother; Bill Richard, his father. (Charles Krupa/AP)
Everything.Title: Boston Marathon bombing trial shifts to the death penalty question

Everything.First paragraph: Authorities in southern California said Tuesday that they will pay more than half a million dollars to a man who was beaten by sheriff’s deputies after a horseback chase earlier this month.
Everything.Caption: (Rick Sforza/The Sun via AP)
Everything.Title: California county will pay $650,000 to man beaten by deputies after chase

First paragraph.text: Five years ago, a 23-year-old hip-hop artist with long hair and a chest full of tattoos, found himself at the center of a national controversy. Atlanta MC Waka Flocka Flame, the man born Juaquin James Malphurs known for his gritty track “Hard in the Paint,” found the song spoofed in a controversial parody video featuring a President Obama impressionist spouting the N-word.

Everything.Caption: Rapper Waka Flocka Flame in 2012. (Kevin Winter/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Waka Flocka Flame’s curious presidential campaign

Everything.First paragraph: This post has been updated.
Everything.Caption: The sun sets on the address where Nav Sarao Futures Ltd. is registered, in London on April 21, 2015. (Neil Hall/Reuters)
Everything.Title: How computerized trading in the hands of a nobody in Britain allegedly crashed the stock market

First paragraph.text: New Zealand Prime Minister John Key is being called a “playground bully” after a waitress claimed that he repeatedly pulled her hair during visits to the cafe where she worked.

Everything.Caption: New Zealand Prime Minister John Key in January 2015 in London. (Carl Court/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: New Zealand’s ponytail-pulling prime minister becomes national embarrassment

First paragraph.text: Pope Francis, who has taken a public role in U.S.-Cuba relations, will visit Cuba on the way to the United States this fall, the Vatican announced Wednesday.

Everything.Caption: Pope Francis leads a Mass for Armenian Catholics marking 100 years since the mass killings of Armenians under the Ottoman Empire, on April 12 at St Peter’s basilica in the Vatican. (Andreas Solaroandreas Solaro / AFP/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Why Pope Francis will visit Cuba on his way to the U.S.

Everything.First paragraph: President Obama will visit an ecologically sensitive national park on Wednesday in a politically sensitive state.
Everything.Caption: A Great Egret looks on in the Florida Everglades on August 5, 2010. (Photo by Joe Raedle/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Obama visits the Everglades to talk about climate change — and goad Republicans to do the same
Here’s Rand Paul wearing sunglasses on the Senate floor and fist bumping Harry Reid

First paragraph.text: [Update: The lawsuit was filed Thursday morning. Head here for more.]

Everything.Caption: Michael Brown’s parents — Lesley McSpadden, left, and Michael Brown, Sr. — during an interview in Washington last year. (Susan Walsh/AP)
Everything.Title: Family of Michael Brown to announce civil suit against the city of Ferguson

Everything.First paragraph: This story has been updated.
Everything.Caption: The Calbuco volcano seen from Puerto Montt, Chile, on April 22. (Alex Vidal Brecas/European Pressphoto Agency)
Everything.Title: Chile’s Calbuco volcano erupts with vivid clouds of ash

Everything.First paragraph: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign on Wednesday accused congressional Republicans of politicizing the deaths of four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, by dragging out an investigation until the waning months of the 2016 election.
Everything.Caption: Democratic presidential candidate and former secretary of state Hillary Rodham Clinton delivers remarks at the Hillary Rodham Clinton Awards for Advancing Women in Peace and Security at Georgetown University on April 22, 2015 in Washington. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Clinton campaign accuses GOP of politicizing American deaths in Benghazi

First paragraph.text: Twenty miles north of Baghdad was not a great place to be in 2004. It was less than a year after the United States invaded Iraq, wreaking widespread destruction as it ousted Saddam Hussein and searched for weapons of mass destruction. And, deployed at Camp Taji, Jim Boyd was feeling lonely — until he found a postcard on the ground with a picture of a pint container of Blue Bell Homemade Vanilla Ice Cream.

Everything.Caption: A freezer in a grocery store Overland Park, Kan.. (Jamie Squire/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Blue Bell, an ‘old-timey, country company,’ vs. Listeria

Everything.First paragraph: “Saturday Night Live’s” Cecily Strong is the most unlikely White House Correspondents’ Dinner host in recent years. She’s famous, but not famous-famous. She’s not a stand-up, nor does she host anything. She’s also not a white man: Strong, 31, is the first female to host since Wanda Sykes in 2009. As such, her speech Saturday could be something special. Don’t know who she is? I’m here to help.
Everything.Caption: “SNL’s” Cecily Strong is the first woman to host the WHCD since 2009. (Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Here’s why Cecily Strong has the comedy chops to host the White House Correspondents’ Dinner

Everything.First paragraph: Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) waded into the high-stakes jockeying for the backing of the billionaire industrialist Koch brothers on Thursday, telling reporters he is "clearly aligned" with them on key issues.
Everything.Caption: Americans for Prosperity Foundation Chairman David Koch. (AP Photo/Phelan M. Ebenhack, File)
Everything.Title: Rubio says he ‘would love to earn’ support of the Kochs

Everything.First paragraph: With the dinner being held tonight, we are re-upping our posts from this week previewing the festivities.
Everything.Caption: Just some nerds at a party before the 2014 Nerd Prom, nerding out. (Photo by Andrew H. Walker/Getty Images for Yahoo News)
Everything.Title: ‘Nerd Prom’ is a gross, self-congratulatory name for the White House Correspondents’ Dinner. Stop.

First paragraph.text: A little more than eight years ago, America’s war in Iraq was in shambles. Thousands of U.S. troops and an untold number of Iraqis were dead. Reports of Saddam Hussein’s “tens of thousands of teaspoons” of anthrax proved unfounded. And the war intended to liberate a nation from a dictator was looking more and more like a huge debacle.

Everything.Caption: Maj. Gen. David Petraeus gave the thumbs up to his troops, family and friends after a ceremony marking his division’s official return from Iraq to Fort Campbell, Ky., on Feb. 14, 2004. (John Sommers II/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Gen. David Petraeus: From hero to zero

Everything.First paragraph: A precarious rescue effort at the top of the world concluded Monday, with daring helicopter pilots ferrying stranded climbers to relative safety from the uppermost reaches of Mount Everest, the world’s deadliest peak.
Everything.Caption: In this photo, released on Monday, a rescue helicopter is shown at Mount Everest’s south base camp. (6summitschallenge.com/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Stranded Mount Everest climbers now rescued

Everything.First paragraph: Indonesia has executed two Australians who had been convicted of drug charges, in a sentence that was was carried out despite global pleas to spare the duo from a firing squad.
Everything.Caption: An October 2010 picture shows Australian Andrew Chan (R) and Myuran Sukumaran (c) talking to their lawyer from inside a holding cell. (EPA/MADE NAGI)
Everything.Title: ‘Bali Nine’ leaders executed by firing squad in Indonesia

First paragraph.text: Thanks to protests last week, the public now knows that some of the workers serving meals to U.S. Senate's members, staff and visitors are paid barely enough to scrape by. Many rely on government benefits like food stamps, and at least one of them -- 63-year-old Charles Gladden -- is homeless, spending his nights outside a downtown Metro station.

Everything.Caption: Charles Gladden, who is homeless, works in the Dirksen Senate Office Building kitchen. (Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post)
Everything.Title: Senate Democrats urge better pay for Capitol jobs contracted out by Senate Democrats

Everything.First paragraph: The National Football League said Tuesday it will end its tax-exempt status, squashing one of America’s most baffling corporate tax breaks and granting the mega-business more secrecy about its inner financial workings.
Everything.Caption: NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell addresses the media at a news conference at the NFL Annual Meeting in Phoenix. (AP Photo/Ross D. Franklin, File)
Everything.Title: The NFL is dropping its tax-exempt status. Why that ends up helping them out.

Everything.First paragraph: The song that made Jack Ely famous is one in which he can hardly be heard.
Everything.Caption: Jack Ely, a co-founder of the Kingsmen best known for his 1963 rendition of the song “Louie Louie,” in 2009. (Don Ryan/AP)
Everything.Title: ‘Louie Louie’ singer Jack Ely dead at 71

First paragraph.text: The Supreme Court on Tuesday heard oral arguments in the four cases consolidated under the title of Obergefell v. Hodges, to consider whether the Constitution requires states to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, and whether states must recognize same-sex marriages performed in other states where they are legal.  Justices appeared somewhat split along ideological lines in their questioning. (Audio may not work on all devices.)

Everything.Caption: This artist rendering shows former Michigan Solicitor General John Bursch making arguments to, from, left, Justices Sonia Sotomayor, Stephen Breyer, Antonin Scalia,, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Samuel Alito Jr. and Elena Kagan. (Dana Verkouteren/AP)
Everything.Title: Supreme Court hears same-sex marriage case: Who said what (with audio)

First paragraph.text: Rishi Khanal is lucky to be alive. The 27-year-old man was trapped inside a collapsed building for about 82 hours alongside three dead bodies before a search-and-rescue team pulled him out on Tuesday. Khanal told the Associated Press: “I had some hope, but by yesterday I’d given up.”

Everything.Caption: (Danish Siddiqui/Reuters)
Everything.Title: The incredible rescue of a Nepal earthquake survivor trapped for 82 hours

Everything.First paragraph: Suzanne Crough, fallen Partridge, in action.
Everything.Caption: “The Partridge Family”: back row, from left, cast members Shirley Jones, Dave Madden, David Cassidy, Susan Dey; and front row, from left, Brian Forster, Danny Bonaduce and Suzanne Crough. (Sony Pictures Television via AP)
Everything.Title: Suzanne Crough, Partridge Family’s clutch tambourine player, is dead at 52

First paragraph.text: California has had a rough go this year. The state’s historic drought is impacting the lives of Californians, and now the drought is exacerbating California’s air pollution, according a new report by the American Lung Association.

Everything.Caption: Birds fly across the sky at daybreak over downtown Los Angeles in 2011. (Frederic J. Brown/AFP/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: The 10 most polluted cities in the U.S.

Everything.First paragraph: In the waning moments of the U.S. war in Vietnam, U.S. Ambassador Graham Martin called for an evacuation of the U.S. Embassy in Saigon. North Vietnamese forces were rolling south toward the city, and thousands of Americans and South Vietnamese needed to be evacuated.
Everything.Caption: In this April 29, 1975, photo, a helicopter lifts off from the U.S. Embassy in Saigon, Vietnam, during last-minute evacuation of authorized personnel and civilians. (AP Photo/File)
Everything.Title: Vietnam remembered: The fall of Saigon in photos, 40 years later

Everything.First paragraph: President Obama traveled five miles from home on Thursday and did something he had never previously done in more than six years in the White House: make an announcement with the mayor of the District of Columbia.
Everything.Caption: President Barack Obama, sitting next to 6th-grader Osman Yaya, a student at Wicomico County Public Schools' Bennett Middle School in Salisbury, Md., speaks at Anacostia Library. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)
Everything.Title: President Obama makes rare appearance with D.C. mayor

Everything.First paragraph: Goodnight, sweet probe.
Everything.Caption: An enhanced color view of Mercury taken by MESSENGER. (NASA)
Everything.Title: The MESSENGER orbiter has crashed into Mercury

First paragraph.text: Every move Oklahoma City Thunder General Manager Sam Presti makes is evaluated by the masses through the same lens: How will it affect Kevin Durant’s decision when he hits free agency in the summer of 2016?

Everything.Caption: Billy Donovan will take over the Oklahoma City Thunder as the team’s new head coach. (John Bazemore/AP Photo)
Everything.Title: Risky Billy Donovan hire shows Thunder concerned about more than just Kevin Durant

Everything.First paragraph: Presumed Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush on Thursday faulted Major League Baseball for keeping fans out of Camden Yards during a Baltimore Orioles game this week, following riots in the city.
Everything.Caption: Former Florida governor Jeb Bush speaks during an event at the Metropolitan University in San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Tuesday. (AP/Ricardo Arduengo)
Everything.Title: Jeb Bush faults Major League Baseball for keeping fans out of Orioles game

Everything.Caption: The NFL draft is underway. (Jerry Lai/USA TODAY Sports)
Everything.Title: NFL Draft 2015: Round 1 analysis – Jameis Winston, Marcus Mariota lead intrigue-free first day; Fantasy impact of top prospects

Everything.First paragraph: A group of students from a Jesuit school in Rome presented Pope Francis with a drone of his very own Thursday, continuing what has become a delightful tradition of giving the pope cool gifts.
Everything.Caption: Pope Francis receives a drone as a gift on Thursday. (Osservatore Romano via EPA)
Everything.Title: Pope Francis has a drone of his very own

Everything.First paragraph:
DEVANTE PARKER
Wide receiver, Louisville
NFL combine measurements: 6-3, 209 pounds 4.45 in the 40
Everything.Caption: (AP Photo/Charles Rex Arbogast)
Everything.Title: 2015 NFL Draft: Fantasy football impact of DeVante Parker to the Dolphins

Everything.First paragraph:
NELSON AGHOLOR
Wide receiver, Southern Cal
NFL combine measurements: 6-0, 198 pounds, 4.42 in the 40
Everything.Caption: (AP Photo/David J. Phillip)
Everything.Title: 2015 NFL Draft: Fantasy football impact of Nelson Agholor to the Eagles

Everything.First paragraph: The U.S.’s largest pneumonic plague outbreak in nearly a century has been identified, and it all started with a sick dog.
Everything.Caption: A 17th century engraving of a “plague doctor” dressed in the heavy gown and beaked mask believed to protect people from the disease. Four people fell ill in a Colorado outbreak of the plague last year. (U.S. National Library of Medicine)
Everything.Title: A Colorado pit bull infected humans with the plague

Everything.First paragraph: This story has been updated.
Everything.Caption: President Obama arrives to deliver remarks on clean energy after a tour of a solar power array at Hill Air Force Base in Utah on April 3.  (Jonathan Ernst/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Why Tesla’s announcement is such a big deal: The coming revolution in energy storage

First paragraph.text: The Reelist is a column featuring Kristen Page-Kirby’s musings on movies. To read Washington Post film critic Ann Hornaday’s review of “The Avengers: Age of Ultron,″ click here.

Everything.Caption: (Marvel/Express Illustration)
Everything.Title: ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron’ shows two very different types of leadership

Everything.First paragraph: Philip Rivers stayed put in San Diego. Adrian Peterson stayed put in Minnesota. There were only two trades. No one moved up to get Marcus Mariota.
Everything.Caption: Though he may not have fit a top need, the Jets got great value landing DE Leonard Williams at No. 6. (Jonathan Daniel/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: 2015 NFL draft grades: Patriots, Seahawks, Jets ace Round 1

Everything.First paragraph: The Department of Justice plans to launch a pilot program aimed at expanding the use of body cameras worn by police officers across the country.
Everything.Caption: A police officer in Colorado poses with a body camera. (Rick Wilking/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Justice Dept. will spend $20 million on police body cameras nationwide

Everything.First paragraph: Updated 4:36 p.m.
Everything.Caption: Parked cars are seen near a part of collapsed structure at the Watergate complex in Washington, Friday, May 1, 2015. District of Columbia rescuers were responding to a structural collapse in the garage at the Watergate complex where one person may be trapped. A spokesman said three stories of the garage apparently collapsed. The area was under construction at the time. (Minh Tran via AP)
Everything.Title: Watergate garage collapses in Northwest D.C.; one person injured

Everything.First paragraph: WITHIN THE CONTEXT of Marvel Studios’ larger cinematic gallery, “Avengers: Age of Ultron” looks like the master canvas.
Everything.Caption: c Magnetic: Captain America gets a major suit improvement in “Age of Ultron.” (courtesy of Disney/Marvel.)
Everything.Title: ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron': A fanboy’s 11-point breakdown of the masterful sequel

First paragraph.text: With their 102-96 win over the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night, the Los Angeles Clippers forced a Game 7 in their first-round NBA playoff series. As is tradition, Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich brought his brevity to the podium to assess Thursday’s loss.

Everything.Caption: San Antonio Spurs guard Manu Ginobili (AP Photo/Chris Carlson)
Everything.Title: Spurs’ bench is key to beating Clippers in Game 7

Everything.First paragraph: This story has been updated.
Everything.Caption: The Tesla Energy Powerwall Home Battery is unveiled by Tesla Motors CEO Elon Musk during an event in Hawthorne, California April 30, 2015. REUTERS/Patrick T. Fallon
Everything.Title: What backing up your home with Tesla’s battery might be like

Everything.First paragraph: Advisers to Bernie Sanders have argued that his grassroots network of small-dollar donors could raise him the roughly $50 million the independent senator from Vermont will need to run a credible, competitive campaign in the Democratic presidential primaries.
Everything.Caption: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) on Capitol Hill Thursday announcing his presidential campaign. (REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst)
Everything.Title: Bernie Sanders raises $1.5 million in 24 hours, says his campaign

Everything.First paragraph: In the decade before her death in 1870, Sophia Smith had a problem. She was the wealthy heir of a Massachusetts farmer, but had no children of her own — what should be done with her fortune? An avid reader with a profound hearing problem, Smith thought about endowing a school for the deaf — but was beaten to the punch when another opened in New England first.
Everything.Caption: Smith College in Northampton, Mass., circa 1900. (Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division)
Everything.Title: Smith College to admit transgender women in historic policy change

Everything.First paragraph: He still has almost two years left in office, but the outlines of President Obama's post-White House life might be starting to take shape.
Everything.Caption: President Obama will be headed to Lehman College in New York to launch the My Brother's Keeper Alliance, a new nonprofit that could keep him busy when he leaves the White House. (Susan Walsh/Associated Press)
Everything.Title: Does Obama’s New York trip offer a glimpse into his post-White House life?

First paragraph.text: For those unfamiliar with Pamela Geller, she was in the news a few weeks ago for sponsoring an ad campaign across major U.S. cities with anti-Muslim posters saying, among other things, “Killing Jews is Worship that draws us close to Allah.”

Everything.Caption: Political blogger Pamela Geller, American Freedom Defense Initiative’s Houston-based founder, speaks at the Muhammad Art Exhibit and Contest, which is sponsored by the American Freedom Defense Initiative, in Garland, Tex., May 3. Two gunmen opened fire on Sunday at the art exhibit, which was organized by an anti-Islamic group and featured caricatures of the prophet Muhammad, and were themselves shot dead at the scene by police officers, city officials and police said. (Mike Stone/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Pamela Geller, the incendiary organizer of Texas ‘prophet Muhammad cartoon contest’

Everything.First paragraph: 1) She started as Cara Carleton Sneed.
Everything.Caption: Carly Fiorina speaks at the Republican Leadership Summit on April 18 in Nashua, N.H. (Jim Cole/AP)
Everything.Title: Nine things to know about Carly Fiorina

First paragraph.text: It is highly unusual for an accomplished executive to be remembered first as a spouse. But that was the case for Dave Goldberg, the chief executive of SurveyMonkey, who died unexpectedly Friday in Mexico at the age of 47, evidently sustaining severe head injuries after falling off a treadmill while on vacation.

Everything.Caption: David Goldberg, CEO of online market researcher SurveyMonkey, in front of the company logo at headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif. Goldberg died unexpectedly Friday in Mexico. (Karsten Lemm/AP)
Everything.Title: Dave Goldberg died from head injuries sustained when he fell off a treadmill

First paragraph.text: Details on Dave Goldberg’s death are still murky. The entrepreneur and husband of Facebook’s chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, was found bleeding out in a Mexican hotel gym on Friday. He died shortly afterward at a nearby hospital, but the strange circumstances are only slowly emerging.

Everything.Caption: (iStock)
Everything.Title: Dave Goldberg’s death points to rise and risks of treadmills in era of smartphones

Everything.First paragraph: “Django Unchained” actress Daniele Watts has agreed as part of a plea deal to apologize to Los Angeles police officers she accused of racism last year.
Everything.Caption: Actress Daniele Watts (left) and Brian Lucas in Los Angeles. (KABC-TV/AP)
Everything.Title: ‘Django Unchained’ actress Daniele Watts ordered to apologize to LAPD cops she accused of racism

First paragraph.text: Two years ago, a best-selling memoir helped make Sheryl Sandberg one of the most famous women in the world. “Lean In” established the Facebook chief operating officer as a powerful female voice preaching hard work and equal pay. She penned opinion pieces and appeared in public service campaigns.

Everything.Caption: Sheryl Sandberg, chief operating officer of Facebook, arrives with her husband, David Goldberg, chief executive of SurveyMonkey, for the first day of a media conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, on July 9, 2014. (Rick Wilking/Reuters)
Everything.Title: Sheryl Sandberg: ‘Unexpected hell’ of husband’s death is ‘darkest and saddest’ moment of my life

First paragraph.text: The NFL is satisfied that it followed its “proper protocol” by not acting prior to the AFC title game on information that the New England Patriots might use improperly deflated footballs, according to a person familiar with league procedures.

Everything.Caption: Roger Goodell and the Patriots appear to be at odds over the DeflateGate investigation. (John Samora/AP Photo)
Everything.Title: NFL believes proper procedures followed when acting on Colts’ DeflateGate tip

Everything.First paragraph: Chris Christie thinks we're all talking about the New England Patriots cheating a little too much. But he also has some thoughts on it.
Everything.Caption: N.J. Gov. Chris Christie and Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones talk prior to the 2015 NFC Divisional Playoff game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field in January in Green Bay, Wisconsin. ( Mike McGinnis/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Chris Christie: Leave Tom Brady alone!

Everything.First paragraph: The chair of the Iowa Republican Party on Thursday announced major changes to the Iowa Straw Poll, part of an aggressive play to salvage the event's role in GOP presidential politics amid persistent questions about its purpose and usefulness.
Everything.Caption: (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster)
Everything.Title: Behind the new Iowa GOP push to save the straw poll

Everything.First paragraph: Famed explorer Barry Clifford believes — once again — that he has finally found the elusive Adventure Galley, the crown jewel of famed pirate Captain William Kidd’s exploits in the Indian Ocean in the 1600s.
Everything.Caption: Madagascar’s President Hery Rajaonarimampianina, second from right, stands in front of a 110-pound silver bar which was allegedly recovered by Marine archaeologist Barry Clifford in the wreck of William Kidd’s ship May 7 on the Island of Sainte Marie. (Manjakahery Tsiresena/AFP/Getty Images)
Everything.Title: Famed explorer says he found the elusive ‘treasure’ ship of Captain Kidd. Not so fast.

First paragraph.text: The day after the DeflateGate report broke — a report that implicated Tom Brady in a cheating scandal that put quite the asterisk next to the New England Patriots Super Bowl win — the star quarterback was scheduled to speak at Salem State University in Salem, Mass. The event sold out within 20 minutes; kids wearing “Brady” jerseys would attend. Canceling the event would look bad, but an ill-conceived, off-message response to a question about DeflateGate would be worse. A scowl, a smirk or even a pregnant pause could spell disaster. Even a “no comment” wasn’t safe.

Everything.Caption: At Salem State University in Salem, Mass., Thursday night, Tom Brady responded to questions about DeflateGate like it wasn’t even a thing. (Pool photo by Charles Krupa via Reuters)
Everything.Title: Tom Brady, the NFL’s unflappable Zen wizard
